It's possible to write SQL that only works on one DBMS, but if you stay
away from things like stored procedures, you're generally OK. A bigger
concern would be the same DBMS on multiple OS platforms, especially
mainframe platforms.

If you decide to use a free DBMS, be sure to get one that runs in
client/server mode. We tried using Cloudscape on a project, which only
ran in embedded mode (well, without paying, anyhow) and that caused us
no end of grief. If your deployment DB will be operating in
client/server mode, make sure your test DB does as well.

That said, you should try to run your tests against the
production/deployment DB, at least using CruiseControl, if you can.

*********** REPLY SEPARATOR  ***********

On 2002-04-19 at 16:43 mailmiked wrote:

>I am trying to unit test some DB code, have read alot of the previous 
>posts and Richard Dallaway's article on the subject. One question 
>that remains unanswered.
>
>Will it work OK to use one type of DB in production (Oracle, in my 
>case) and another type of DB to test against (something free, like 
>mySQL)? I am nowhere near a SQL Guru. Couldn't we have some SQL that 
>didn't work for both systems, or is that rare?
>
